thread.title: End of rip-off rail fares as ticket pricing system gets overhaul
thread.title_full: End of rip-off rail fares as ticket pricing system gets overhaul

author: Patrick Sawer
title: End of rip-off rail fares as ticket pricing system gets overhaul
text:
T he sale of rail tickets is to undergo a complete overhaul to stop passengers being ‘ripped off’ and to make the cost of journeys cheaper and easier to understand.
Passengers will be offered the cheapest available ticket for a through journey, without having to compare if it would be cheaper to buy individual tickets for each section of the route run by different rail operators, as at present.
And travellers will be shown the best available price for a journey, regardless of whether they are buying a return ticket or two single tickets.
The reforms follow a rail watchdog investigation into “rip off” rail machines after a Telegraph investigation revealed that passengers are routinely being denied the cheapest fares .
Watch | Commuters protest in song over price rises 01:13 P revious research has suggested that one in 20 passengers were being sold rail tickets by machines that are too expensive.
This means the millions of rail passengers could be potentially be paying the wrong train fares for journeys.
An investigation by the Telegraph in 2014 found that customers were forced to pay double the required fare as a result of machines promoting the most expensive tickets and “burying” the cheapest options.
Our investigation also found that rail firms failed to offer cheaper fares sold at other operators’ machines just feet away.
The reforms, being piloted by the Rail Delivery Group (RDG) on routes between London and Sheffield and on CrossCountry Trains’ nationwide network, will lead to the most radical overhaul of fares system for more than 30 years.
The RDG says the new system will mean more user-friendly ticket vending machines and make it easier to get the right ticket at the best price, either online or at stations.
Trials of new pricing, simpler routes to give customers clearer choices, and the removal of unnecessary and unwanted fares from the system are due to start in May this year on selected routes.
Estimated | 2017 rail fare increases J acqueline Starr, RDG Managing Director of Customer Experience, said: “We know customers can find it hard to get the right ticket for their journey due to complex rules and regulations built up by governments over decades. There are more than 16 million different train fares, many of which nobody buys. This also makes it more difficult to give passengers the right, simple options on ticket machines.
“Working with government, we’re determined to overhaul the system to cut out red-tape, jargon and complication to make it easier for customers to buy fares they can trust, including from ticket machines.”
If the pilot scheme is rolled out across the network is will mean the end of decades-old government rules covering rail fares, which were originally intended to protect customers but were introduced before the internet and online booking and have prevented train companies from being more flexible in offering tickets that customers want.
The RDG has also issued a ten point Ticket Vending Machine improvement plan for rail operators to make ticket vending machines easier to use and the information printed on tickets easier to understand.
Rail fares T his will include making passengers aware that a cheaper ticket is available for the same journey, meaning, according to the RPG, that “customers never unknowingly pay more for a ticket than they needed”.
The planned changes were welcomed by the independent watchdog Transport Focus.
Anthony Smith, its chief executive, said: "What’s clear from our research is that passengers find the ticketing system far too complex. The presence of cheaper fares that are 'hidden' in the system really damages trust between passengers and train companies.
“These trials are a welcome step in providing clearer information on ticket restrictions and greater transparency on price. We will be monitoring these measures to make sure passengers are getting a better deal."
